Working for this company was stressful, but I always felt valued. Most admin jobs in healthcare right now pay $18 per hour, Northwell pays $22 per hour. Patients come first, this makes my job easier when patients feel like they matter.
cons: Their structure changed after the pandemic, front desk, surgical coordinators, and billers became administrative assistants and everyone is cross trained to do multiple jobs in the event someone is out sick for an extended period of time. If you are applying for roles within Northwell your manager will find out, can stop you from leaving. Sometimes it's easier to just move onto another company. Also, if you start with their temp agency, get hired, and move on to another job not within the company you cannot get back in through the temp agency

review_title: Decent Culture; Salary/Benefits are Not Competitive
job_title: Supervisor Pharmacy Operations in Westbury, NY
pros: The culture is alright. They promote being the best healthcare employer in NY and among the top in the US.
cons: Salaries are not competitive at all. Other healthcare systems in NY pay ~$40k more than Northwell pays. However, those organizations may be a bit more cutthroat. The bonus structure is inconsistent. Salary increases are below inflation and not truly based on merit. You have to take money away from one employee to give more to another employee. If all employees are high performers, you can only give an average salary increase. So, it doesn't pay to be a high performer. NYC has significantly better benefits. A lot of the culture is a facade for awards/recognition/attention/public relations. It's not as great as advertised. Promotions are extremely difficult because they prioritize "years of experience" over "actual experience" and accomplishments. The organization is also run by people with many years of experience. They are highly accomplished, but they are out of touch with the current generation's needs, leading to an enormous amount of inefficient back-to-back meetings. They advertise being diverse, but there's really only 1 executive leader who is considered diverse. Everyone else is white, elderly, and mostly male. There are too many "urgent" requests to have things completed within a day or a week. There are too many times that we're contacted off hours and not compensated. Nurses are prioritized over all other professions due to unions and settlements, resulting in lower pay for everyone except for physicians and executives. There are nurses getting $200+/hr.

job_title: PSA/Patient Safety Assistant in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: Free parking for the staff
cons: Working for Northwell long-term is not viable unless you have a great support system outside of work. The PSA position is a floating position to fulfill coverage needs. You don't have a designated workspace, you don't have a designated time to take 15mins breaks/lunch (it's contingent upon who you're covering for-and often times, more senior staff take advantage of newest members). Management presence is minimal. When you finally get access to management and voice a concern, you get gaslighted, and they like to blame the victim. The more senior staff are so fed up that they've checked out which in turn put the burden on the newbie to pick up the tab. Overall, the staff is cold, vindictive, and engage in workplace bullying. They even make fun of the vulnerable/development disabled patients that comes to the office. Sometimes, they staff could be overheard talking about their personal business and having conversations inappropriate for the workplace. With management and supervisors, there was often awkwardness as well as condescending, patronizing behavior. One positive aspect was the position is unionized, so you can always transfer internally after the first year.

review_title: Review of Long Island Jewish Medical Center Specifically (all locations are different)
job_title: Human Resources Business Partner HRBP in New Hyde Park, NY
pros:
Reputation - largest employer in NY State
Career Movement - lots of open positions and transferring within the system is not looked down upon
People - Tons of employees are caring, smart, and driven. Super down to earth (no stuffy or super corporate environment)
PTO - this is not the same for everyone (depends on job title and experience), but for someone at my level is 32 right off the bat which is amazing (combines vacation and sick, so one bucket for both). There are also 9 holidays.
cons:
Benefits - medical is not the cheapest, kind of locked into going to Northwell facilities only, but they do have a rewards program that gives you money back for completing health activities (even with that it's more expensive than other companies, which is ironic seeing as it's a hospital chain)
Corporate teams are horrible - Compensation, Talent Acquisition (recruitment), Onboarding, Payroll... every single specialty team from Corporate is horrible. They make tons of mistakes, take forever to respond back or simply never do, refuse to speak to employees directly so Site HR is left having to play middleman with angry employees for issues that don't even concern us - and there's absolutely ZERO accountability for all of this. This is 100% my least favorite part of the job, and I believe Corporate should be cleaned up of inefficient and incompetent employees and it needs to be restructured to better support the sites and employees it's meant to actually support. 
Pay - very low salary bands for most positions. Because of this, it's extremely hard to attract and retain talent, so most departments that you can think of are horribly understaffed
Angry employees - if you are going to work in HR, just know that employees here have no qualms about taking their anger out on you. I've never worked in any industry in which people can be so rude and demanding - HR candidates beware!
Diversity & Inclusion - DE&I is an afterthought here. My team tries to create change but it falls on deaf ears. Yes DE&I is part of Northwell's marketing and values, but it's all talk. It does not actually translate to every day practices and it's not at the forefront of people's minds. Leaders and employees are can be outwardly racists.

job_title: PRACTICE OFFICE ASSOCIATE in New York, NY

job_title: Director in Nassau, NY
pros: Large Health System with maximum resources in reach. Reasonably decent place for front line workers. Great place for white males of any age. Great place for young white females.
cons: It’s like a club house. Unconnected people can get to a director level. The executive, and regional level jobs are not for hard workers. They are reserved for those who are connected to the people at the top whether hard/smart workers or not. Friends and Family plan. Also they respond to government regulations on physician practice by buying the physician practices and putting all the cost on hospitals so the government goal of savings is never accomplished. Basically a bailout. Corporate strategy and the wealthy will always find a way to work around government regulations and keep the rich rich. Physicians are layered with titles and added pay associated with titles, as well as corporate cards and tax write-offs in order to keep them happy. Managers and administrators are not recognized for anything. Their work is often credited to the physicians to make the physicians feel valued. Decisions aren’t made with healthcare in mind. Finance is calling all the shots. Michael Dowling has values but is more of a spokesman now than anything else and the finance arm of the system is basically reducing the corporate values to the likes of the hotel industry.

Michael Dowling and Northwell wish to become the nanny state of NY, telling everyone what to do.

job_title: Research Assistant in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: Overtime, free food ocassionally, pay is very decent (but tbh not worth it in my opinion...see below).
cons:
- Poorly trained management (I can probably write an essay on this, but just to name a few things: I noticed multiple managers talking down to their employees, lots of favoritism/politics, PTO was frowned upon the few times I did ask for it). Not true for all managers, but this was my experience and the experience of a few other ppl I knew from other departments). 
- Disorganized workflows, administrative work and tech is still stuck somewhere in the early 2000s...
 - As much as they preach the emphasis of a positive patient experience, I've noticed that unless you're in a managerial or executive position, you are treated like trash. At first I thought it was just me, and my boss somehow had something against me for some reason...then after quite some time (I worked there for 2.5 years),
- very limited mobility in research unless you have a PhD
- For being a health system, insurance is really not great. They only allow you to use the Northwell health system which is mostly in long island. So if you commute from nyc, nj, or anywhere else in the tri-state, you're stuck with high OOP costs.
- Disclaimer: Northwell has tens of thousands of employees and several locations. This is all based on my experience during my time there.

job_title: PRACTICE OFFICE ASSOCIATE in Patchogue, NY
pros: Time off..every paycheck you get a few hours
cons:
The raises are based on percentages of your hourly rate from 0-6% and “nobody get 6% Bc you can always do better” so if you make 16 an hour with a 3% raise you get .48 cents which it’s annual. Northwell health pay THE LOWEST of any other healthcare corporation meanwhile they’re making billions and capitalizing off of the coronavirus.

This corporation is big in favoritism so if you are an individual with your own opinions-good luck! My old manager who quit Bc his higher up spoke negatively about him to other higher ups while he was standing there. They also treated him poorly and forced him out. But he told me “in order to get promoted you need to say yes to everything they ask”..as long as you say yes to EVERYTHING you will go far. It does not matter if u work better harder n take more initiative and get stuff done compared to everyone else, if u go against the grain you will be left to rot. 

They will tell you, you need to work in this office from now on or you can leave and force you to relocate. This has happened to numerous people I had worked with.

This company does not care about the employees do not let them fool you. Just look at all the people who dedicated their lives lost time with their family and pushed through the toughest times during the pandemic all fired or forced to go against their morals and beliefs. 

I can not wait until northwell is forced to compensate them!

review_title: No Support from Leadership, Low Pay, Long Hours
job_title: Talent Acquisition in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: Northwell Health had developed a great reputation during the pandemic, so it’s a great company to have on your resume to say you have worked there. Benefits are descent, especially if all you funnel your medical needs through Northwell Health Physicians. Benefit information is available to the public if you Google it.
cons: If you work in HR, TA, or CORP, be prepared for ESCALATION CULTURE, NO support from your managers and leaders who have no idea what you do and demand more of you. NO IN LINE PROMOTIONS in TA. They claim there is growth opportunity, but there isn’t much growth. There is a bit of nepotism but not within the same departments, however leaders use their title to get their relatives through the door. So the application process for growth can be falsified. The blame is on the employee if they can’t move up, however they seemingly have ore-selected candidates for any growth opportunities one can apply to.  The Match on your retirement plans is a lot less than other companies, and the vesting period is 6 years (huge turnover at NWH,  perhaps that’s why). Benefits are much more expensive at the corporate level than the hospital, so it’s not uniform throughout the system.  They aren’t actually diverse and inclusive, especially at the leadership level. Non BIPOC/POC women over 40 are shouldn’t count, because that’s the majority of their staff, but it appears they do so it seems as if they are “diverse and inclusive.” HR does not work together, at all. Partnership should be at all levels, however, since the HR specialties are all separated, there is no real sense of “ONE HR,” aka ONE TEAM. Promotions are mainly seen at executive levels throughout the organization. Lower level staff who make then organization keep running, are left out of the growth opportunity. You have to leave and come back if you want to be considered.

review_title: Terrible Department in a Great Hospital
job_title: Food Service Worker in Manhasset, NY
pros: The pay and benefits were good. Overall, I believe the organization cares about its employees the way it cares about its patients. They are very engaging, always looking for ways to improve in areas and to share information with everyone alike. Good opportunities around the organization if you have the goal and drive. As an ORGANIZATION.
cons: Get some popcorn and enjoy for this one you will need it. Now, while the organization overall is great, then you have specific hospitals and then you have all the departments you can work for. I loved NSUH, but working in the dietary/nutrition department was a terrible experience. I actually want to know what the qualifications are for running this department because the way they behave, I feel like a group of monkeys can come together and do a better job. Managers plays favorites with employees and it’s the worst I’ve seen in all my years. They will clock in/out friends/employees without them being there. They will pay certain friends/employees when they’re on vacation PTO when they’re not in a qualified position for PTO. They will even step in to do their friends/employees job when that employee has disapprove the locker room or even worse, left the hospital altogether to go outside to drink, or smoke, go to the store, whatever they feel like doing. You even have certain “leaders” in the kitchen who were selling drugs at nighttime. Nighttime is the worst shift by far to work here you can ask anyone. No serious supervision or management at night (it’s normally during the day) so taking advantage, the supposed supervisors they have to manage are letting their friends do whatever they want. Drink, smoke, eat. It’s terrible at night nobody wants to work this shift because if you’re not friends with the supervisors, you’re left to do everything their friends don’t want to do while they hang out downstairs. If you’re a guy and you don’t want to sleep or flirt with the night leads, you will be left to do everything. If you’re a fellow WOMAN, it’s even worse because you’re a threat so you don’t stand a chance. Overall, the favoritism is out of hand. Management is never coordinated and on one team. Treat you like robots and you end up miserable. Work anywhere but in dietary it will be a sad mistake. I have to write this here because actually talking to upper-management or HR doesn’t work, you’re wasting your time. They just go back to their supervisors and tell them what you said and will even coach them on how to retaliate you without you knowing. Yeah they play both sides all the time, extremely fake and two-faced, so honestly don’t trust yourself talking to any of them. Just prepare yourself to leave altogether. I have to write and expose this here hoping maybe it reaches the right people to investigate and make improvements. Or to save ANYONE from making a mistake applying to this department.

job_title: Accounts Payable Analyst in New Hyde Park, NY
pros: It is convenient to get to work if you live nearby. Parking spots are always available. Health benefits and PTO days are excellent. Excellent for people starting their career without a college degree. Opportunities to advance in education is available. You can register for classes and get paid for the day when class is in session. Class is located in the building. Co-workers are friendly. Communicating with Vendors and purchase order team allows us to learn about the accounts payable processes. Job is great for people who are great with data entry and fixing problems.
cons: Management is not that great. Work is not evenly distributed. Workers have a negative taste of the job. Favoritism does exists. Micro managing does occur. We are basically fixing errors on invoices to pay out. No accounting involved. Mostly data entry and making sure purchase order matches invoice to pay. Unfinished projects are handed down to new employees or current employees after someone leaves. Some employees work hard and some don't. No consequences for those who don't work hard. No rewards for those who works hard. It is a routine day to day job. Managers set up supervisors to watch employees if they leave work early or talk too much in halls, etc. Receptionist is also watching employees and reporting to management.
